div.head: Description of Monument
div.p: White marble block, chipped along all edges and also on the surface ; there are dowel-holes for an attachment above.

div.head: Description of Text
div.p: Inscribed on the face. This is the conclusion of a text which must have been laid out in several columns. The supplements are hardly in doubt. In 1. 5 the long vacat at the end is likely to have been balanced by another at the beginning and that seems to be confirmed by the little that survives of the surface there.

div.head: Translation
div.p: having also been astynomos and neopoios and strategos in charge of the city-territory, and many times strategos in charge of the city, and having successfully carried out a number of very important embassies on behalf of his country; and having been active for (her) freedom and laws and the right of asylum and the privileges granted to her; and been honoured in all these things which he brought about and in his magistracies and liturgies.

div.head: Commentary
div.p: The letter-forms of the inscription are comparatively early and seem to show resemblances to those of inscriptions honouring Zoilos in the theatre (late thirties - early Augustan); so that, although the formulae relating to embassies can be more easily paralleled in the first century A.D., there may be a case for associating the subject with the first grant of privileges to Aphrodisias in 39 B.C. and, indeed, for proposing tentatively his identification as Solon, son of Demetrios (docs. 8.25, ll. 14 f.; 8.27, 1. 22; 8.31, ll. 4--5). See further Aphrodisias and Rome, 166-167.
